stakeholders.title: Victims
actions: Recognize that abuse is not 'normal'.
Understand that 'no-one deserves to be treated like that'.
Learn about abuse – the dangers of staying in an abusive relationship, what not to do, and how to leave/escape safely.
Identify support system: family, friends, co-workers that might help.
Seek help and advice from domestic violence hotlines, advocates, and other service providers.

attitudes.info: This is just how life is.
If I leave, I have no money to support myself.
If I try to leave, my abuser will kill me and harm my children.
I love my abuser. Given time I can change him/her.
Who can I tell, I am so embarrassed and ashamed.
It's my duty to keep the family together.
Why call the police? They come, but they don't help.

stakeholders.title: Perpetrators
actions: Acknowledge action and accept responsibility.
Seek professional help.
Enroll in an anger management class.

attitudes.info: If I cannot have her/him, nobody can.
She/He went out without telling me. She/He refused to have sex with me.
I cannot live without her/him.
She/He burned the food. I just lost my temper, I am sorry.
She/He doesn’t do anything to help. All she/he does is nag.
It’s okay. I did not hit her/him.

stakeholders.title: E-911 Call Takers (operators)
actions: Information gathering – asking appropriate questions to gather needed information
Reassuring and calming caller – effective communication skills
Dealing effectively with special population – non-English speaking, LGB
Determining severity – assessment; knowledge of danger assessment tool
Decision-making – disposition of calls (connecting to services & resources)
Summarizing and documenting call
Recognizing workplace stresses – burnout and Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD)

attitudes.info: She/HE was out-of-line and should be a better wife/husband.
It’s just a lover’s quarrel. They can work it out.
How am I to determine who started the fight?
Here we go again. They just keep calling.

stakeholders.title: Police Officers
actions: Use caution approaching scene and check all parties for injuries.
Ascertain whereabouts of the abuser and assess dangerousness.
If abuser is present, separate the parties and interview them out of hearing range of each other.
Determine relationship of victim to suspect.
If present, what does abuser say happened? What does victim say? (Put each party’s response in quotes). Document any excited utterances and spontaneous statements.
Obtain statements from all parties, including witnesses and children (recorded statements preferred). Describe physical/emotional state of each party (crying, shaking, flushed face, etc.)
What did you observe related to the accounts of events/injuries?
Describe injuries (type, size, location, color).
Collect evidence and document/list damaged property (broken phone, torn clothing, bloody items, damaged walls, knocked over furniture, etc.)
Do children present or reside in the house? Contact appropriate authorizes, if warranted.
Take pictures of scene, victim, suspect, and children.
Determine who called 911? Obtain statement and 911 recording.
Obtain and note previous history of domestic violence.
Is there a protective order? Is the suspect on probation?
Obtain an expedited warrant, if suspect cannot be locate.
If medical attention required: Release signed? Obtain statements about the extent of injuries from medical personnel.
Do not discuss whether victim should prosecute.
Obtain name, address and phone number of someone (mother, best friend, relative, etc.), who will know how to reach victim.

attitudes.info: She/He was out-of-line and should be a better wife/husband.
It’s just a lover’s quarrel. They can work it out.
How am I to determine who started the fight?
How do I determine whether arrest is appropriate?
Here we go again. I don’t understand why she/he doesn’t just leave.
When victims refuse help and do not press charges, they deserve what they get.
Dealing with these cases requires lots of time.
I’m not a social worker. I became an officer to find the bad guys.
Domestic violence calls can be very dangerous. You never know if the abuser is still present. If their abuser is still there, you don’t know what they are going to do.

stakeholders.title: Emergency Medical Technicians (EMT) and Paramedics
actions: Front-line, providing pre-hospital care of injuries.
Assess the home environment.
Care for injuries first.
Offer resource if domestic violence is suspected.
Development of an assessment tool to determine risk for domestic violence.

attitudes.info: I’m a first responder to an injury call. I just take care of the injury.
All I can do is to encourage the victim to seek help.
I get an injury call, how am I supposed to diagnosis domestic violence?
There is nothing about domestic violence on the forms I am required to fill out.
Victim didn’t want to go to the hospital, what am I supposed to do?
Couples get into fights, she/he probably was nagging him/her and he/she hit her/him.
